did.unittitle: Morton N. Katz Papers
did.abstract: This collection details experience of Morton N. Katz as he served in The U.S. Army, Airborne Division, during World War II. The collection contains army correspondence, regimental history, memoir, photographs, and oral history interview.
did.physloc: Center for Public Policy and Social Research (CPPSR) 207 DiLoreto Hall, Central Connecticut State University (CCSU) 1615 Stanley St. New Britain, CT 06050

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Morton N. Katz was commissioned into the U.S. Army through the reserves program in 1940. After the attack on Pearl Harbor, he was ordered to attend training in Fort Benning, Ga. He completed infantry training and then went on for an additional six weeks of training with the parachute infantry. From there he was sent to England with the 503rd parachute infantry as a replacement battalion. Katz's unit prepared for the invasion of North Africa; however, they ended up arriving in Iran by train. His battalion then went to Italy, and by October of 1943 they were involved in combat near Naples. His unit was attached to the 82nd airborne division, and they went on to be part of the Anzio invasion and the Battle of the Bulge. When the Germans finally surrendered, the 82nd airborne division liberated Wobbelin concentration camp, which was a starvation camp outside of Ludwigslust, Germany. Katz was sent home in early 1946, but he remained in the reserves. He went on to use the G.I. Bill to attend law school, but he still took assignments with the reserves between semesters. After graduation from law school he accepted a position with the Civil Affairs Unit, where he stayed for 17 years. He was promoted to Colonel and served at the Pentagon. Katz kept in close touch with many from his unit, attending reunions of the 82nd Airborne Division Association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "All volunteers, but McLaney became chief rigger of the 509th Parachute Infantry Battalion. At Fort Benning, GA, on August 16, 1940, he orchestrated the U.S. Army’s 1st mass static line jump. As a result, August 16th is known as National Airborne Day. U.S. Army Photograph"
